title: OpenConnectManagementThread: Revert back to old SHA1 cert hash
message:
OpenConnectManagementThread: Revert back to old SHA1 cert hash

Commit 948a60430ff5e0 ("Use new Java API to get peer cert") inadvertently
changed the format of the certificate hash, which would cause previously
accepted certs to generate a new warning.  The new scheme only hashes a
portion of the cert; the traditional cert fingerprint computes the SHA1
of the entire DER file.

So for now we will manually implement the latter scheme and preserve
compatibility with existing stored hashes.

See also:
http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.network.vpn.openconnect.devel/1956/focus=2113

Signed-off-by: Kevin Cernekee <cernekee@gmail.com>

title: OpenConnectManagementThread: Fix regression on CSD fixup
message:
OpenConnectManagementThread: Fix regression on CSD fixup

Commit a543c06cf428 (Allow use of x86 Linux CSD wrapper scripts) added
logic to check for e.g. "#!/bin/sh" at the start of the script, and
prepend "#!/system/bin/sh" if the interpreter was missing.  In a
subsequent commit, d08793cfcb (Copy certs into individual files), this
logic was inadvertently bypassed; stored CSD scripts would be used as-is
instead of rewritten to add the corrected interpreter line.

So, for any stored file for which isExecutable == true, we will copy
the contents to a temporary file and change the interpreter if necessary.
Handling of actual certs (not CSD scripts) should be unaffected.

title: OpenConnectManagementThread: Fix base64 stored file detection
message:
OpenConnectManagementThread: Fix base64 stored file detection

Android's base64 decoder rejects "some" bad inputs, but not all of them.
This means that if a VPN profile had stored a literal certificate instead
of a base64-encoded certificate (as was the case in <= 0.7), it might get
decoded into junk data.  Through experimentation and reading the source
code, it was shown that inputs like "a&bc" or "ab*c" do not raise
exceptions.

So we will add a regexp to reject any base64 string with invalid
characters.  At the minimum this should cause PEM files starting with
"-----BEGIN " to be processed as literal values, not as base64.

Signed-off-by: Kevin Cernekee <cernekee@gmail.com>
